1.content:
You glance over the world you call home...
Grethbean...

It has always been home to you and your kind..
In such, you have tried to keep it peaceful and keep trouble away from your clan.

It is not always easy...however...
as you start your patrol, you pass a nearby pond.
You peer into the water and see your reflection....

What do you see?
1.title: The beginning of it all

12.content:
You just gaze into the pond and see a mirror image of yourself gaze back. All of your features are there, long brown hair, small rounded nose, deep blue eyes and your well rounded face. On your back sits a long broadsword with a brown, leathered hilt. Looking down you see your silver plated chain mail armour covering your brown tunic underneath.

Turning away from the pond, you look up to see an array of birds flying in a perfect formation overhead. Whilst you stare in awe at the birds you suddenly become aware of a nearby bush rustling. You turn your sharp gaze towards the bush and see it rustle again. Slowly and steadily, you begin taking steps towards the small green berry bush. As you slowly stride towards the bush it grows calm and becomes stationary once again. You kneel down beside the small flora, pull apart the leaves carefully and peer inside only to have your eyes met by...
12.title: guardian of the human race

131.content: You stared into the puddle and saw yourself, a dwarf about middling height for a dwarf, your beard had been trimmed to no more than a chinstrap which was the longest any guardians facial hair was allowed to grow, the elves and few orcs who were part of the guardians had no problem with this seeing as how they couldn't grow facial hair and the humans generally kept their haira trimmed short with the exception of a few. But for Dwarfs this was a major social problem because this was how dwarfs showed age, the oldest of Dwarfs beards would trail behind them, sometimes for minutes!
131.title: the dwarfs

choices: you see something in the distance
132.content:
Standing on the cliffs edge, you stare over the valley of Nosferus.
It is your home...the home of the dragons.

You are Kihara..a male dragon youngling.
You are 130 years old..still a baby in dragon years.

Yet, the clan trusts you to keep watch over the entrance to Nosferus.
They need to make sure noone invades and tries to wipe out your people.
That is your duty.

You hear a voice behind you.
"Another quiet day eh Kihara?"

You turn to face your friend...Lyzann.
He is a blue dragon...335 years old.
Why he decided to be friends with you...you'll never know.

"Yes...as usual.
But then again..that is for the best."
Lyzann laughs.
"You should come back to Nosferus.
My family is planning a celebration and i am inviting you."

You frown.
" I can't.
I must guard this position until nightfall.
If i leave and we are invaded..."

Lyzann grabs you by your scales.
"Please...
No-one even knows about Nosferus..let alone where it is.
Take a break...
We're having Sky parrot stew."

You love Sky parrot stew..
* I suppose it couldn't hurt to leave it for today*
132.title: a rare commodity

1322.content:
" I can't Lyzann.
My job is to stay here and guard Nosferus.
That is what i shall do."
Lyzann smiles.

" I understand.
I will save some for you when you return."
As he heads back to his house in Nosferus, the sun shines on you.

Your light blue scales glimmer in the evening sun.
Your black eyes scan the valley swiftly and silently.
You tail slices the air ferociously.

You wish you could have gone with Lyzann...
But the clan needs you here.
The sky parrot stew would have to wait.

A subtle wind passes by your nose.
You sniff...and sense something.
You sniff again..trying to identify the source.

Suddenly..it comes to you!
1322.title: stay and guard the cliffside

choices: The cultists were wiped out or burned. You wake and seek the fate of your clan.
The cultists survived. Using the braziers, they capture and transport you away.
13221.content:
The smells are mostly familiar: the musk of hounds and beasts of burden, the acrid smoke of pine in their torches. The pinguid stench of greed and lust for fortune in their sweat comes to you just as easily. However, there is a tinge of something new mixed in to these scents- it's sharp like a spice, and stinks like the garlic that grows over the mountain range, but heavier, angrier.

You waste no time and unfurl your wings, plunging gracefully from the cliff side. In a dynamic arc, you ride the winds high into the air and let out a shrill roar; a signal to the older dragons of danger approaching. The sun's light has not yet ducked under the mountain tops to the west, and the human hunters spot you almost immediately, pointing and drawing their weapons. You circle high above them- hopefully out of arrow range, yet daring them to try- and wait for the clan. Time passes and you watch the hunters light up fires and spread out at the edge of a clearing, using the treeline for safety.

There is still no response from the clan. You signal again. After a wait, you try once more even louder. Why is there no response? Are they unable to hear you over Lyzann's party? It is unlike them to make the kind of racket that would require. If you delay any longer, the hunters could scatter into the forest and reassemble elsewhere. It will be dark soon, too. Eyeing the eerie light of the hunters' torches, just a bit too bright and red to be pine, you decide to advance alone.

You are young still, but as a hunter yourself, your instincts are sharp. Without any warning or noise, you fold your wings close to your scaly form and begin a dive towards the men. The wind whips past your face and the men seem a hundred beats closer every moment. If your nostrils weren't closed to block against the incredible wind velocity, you would undoubtedly smell their terror. It is instinctual in man; an immutable fact of nature that they fear the sight of this dive just as a mouse fears an owl, or a fish fears a shark.

In the brief moments before you are upon them, you notice several oddities in the party. Their clothing is dark, twisted and spiny, like a charred newt near a bonfire. Their ponies and mules are adorned with the same shimmering black armor, and carrying blood red tapestries where there would usually be tarps and bags. The fires they had lit, the ones that burned too bright and red, were not torches, but rather iron braziers, staked into the ground with what might have been polished bone. Their weapons were those of hunters- bow and arrow, sling and rock- but they carried long, slender blades at their sides that no woodsman would have use for. In your relative youthfulness, you could not yet know their proper names, but you are learned enough to guess their volition: these are demon worshipers.

Tucked into the treeline and spread out, the cultists are safe from a clean dive bomb. Instead, you swoop as low into the clearing as you are able. Your nostrils reopen- the scent of terror is overpowered by their garlic stench- and take a deep breath. Your chest is suddenly almost two thousand degrees. Before you crash into the treeline, you arc up just enough to clear the canopy and then unload your fiery breath into the party with a fearsome roar. The heat of the fire disintegrates the clearing's meadow grasses in an instant as the brilliant orange and blue flames light up the dusk. The treeline positively explodes: old pines ignite like match sticks, the duff of the forest floor is replaced with a burning lake. Branches crumple, wood shrieks. You are arcing back into the sky and preparing for another salvo before the first has even touched down.

Over the din of destruction, you roar your only spoken warning. Your voice is thunderous, hard and ancient, despite its speaker.

"Humans, leave this forest now or perish!"

As you circle back over the clearing to prepare for another pass, you feel a cold tingle in your right side. You glance down and spy barbed red arrows with black feathers lodged between your scales. Ordinarily, a dragon's scales act as much like armor as any suited knight, but bows were used to puncture armored suits when they first saw use in war. As a young dragon, your scales have not hardened to their full strength either. These barbed shafts seem to be poisoned, judging from the sting. What a nuisance. This proved the cultists were not out for game; you can't eat a poisoned catch.

you swipe the arrows out of your side and bear down again on the clearing. You can see that your breath has charred a swath of forest and every unfortunate cultist that it caught has burnt into something indistinguishable from the trees. However, they were properly spread out around the clearing beforehand; this will take several more passes unless they retreat. You wish the other dragons had joined you by now, but there's nothing else to do about it.

You whiz over the clearing and collect your breath again. It fills your heart with draconian strength and makes the pelting of fresh arrows around your wings and face seem as insignificant as bug bites. You spy a bearer of one of the braziers and his mule behind a sickly pine ahead. The gout of flame blasts from your mouth with even more force this time, obliterating the cultist and everything around him. The colors again blaze over the treeline in reds, oranges and blues. Pine sap burns very well. It is unfortunate that you must burn down your clan's own forests to be rid of these invaders.

On the next pass over the clearing, you are startled to find that you can't feel your right arm. As the surge of power leaves your heart, you feel drained and numb. You have to work much harder to beat your right wing then you should, and your head is heavy. The poison is much stronger than you thought and it startles you. You slow and try signalling one last time, as loudly as you possibly can. But, you can't stop here: if the cultists have brought such a toxin with them, they could do far worse given time to retreat. They could hide away until they find Nosferus. They could slip through in the night, and target the newborns or-

-or the sky parrot stew.

A new sense of panic fills your chest. Not of these men themselves, but of the new peril your clan is in, and the worry of losing them. Nobody has responded to your final call. It falls to you, then. You fight through the numbing sting spreading through your limbs, rake your claws over the arrows in your face, and descend on the clearing once more. These devil worshipers ought to pray to whatever petty deity they followed; a dragon's wrath is a force of nature.

Using the light of the fires as a backdrop, you scan for the remaining cultists hiding in the trees. There aren't many of them, but they are even more spread out now than before. They notch their bows as you come close, the light reflecting off of their twisted black armor like poised scorpions. You feign another dive, and then rear up in the center of the clearing. The arrows come like hail, but you shrug them off and take a deep breath, as deep as you can muster. The fire in your chest again fills you with that ancient, indomitable will that has made dragons the most feared creatures in the known world, almost more so than the inferno that follows.

You quickly find the first cultist at the furthest left position and let your breath flow forth. But you don't stop there; between the beats of your wings, you sweep your flames right, torching the entire treeline and causing the whole clearing to ignite into a hellish landscape. At the furthest rightmost cultist, you sweep back again. Still, the arrows fly into your belly and wings. One makes its way into your throat and pierces the soft flesh of your tongue, but you take another breath and return it a thousandfold.

The clearing is getting very dark- and not just from the sun. Your thoughts have to swim through a thick syrup to register, and your whole body is numb save for your burning heart. Like some loathsome parasite, the cultists persevere despite the pyroclasm, scuttling through the burning forest as it falls to pieces around them. One with a gleaming golden horned helmet looks like he means to charge you. He is suddenly crushed under a great falling pine, squashed like bug. You huff small, exhausted, involuntary flames through your nostrils in satisfaction.

In that moment, you lose your breathing rhythm, and your fiery core is extinguished. Your wings betray you and you slump to the ground. At this point only your neck will respond to your demands. Surrounded by the warmth of the hellish meadow, you could fall to sleep in a moment. But is your clan safe? Are they even aware? Are they... you dare not consider it. You slowly, drunkenly survey the forest. The cultists are out of sight, but there could be more in hiding. Or they could have joined the new reserves of charcoal.

At five points along the edge, you see the bony braziers which have miraculously remained in place through the blaze. Each now burns with a sickly green fire instead of a red one. You suppose if they weren't lit beforehand, you certainly ignited them yourself. It matters not at this point. Nothing matters but sleep.
13221.title: Human hunting party...sound the alarm

choices: Everywhere is Shabelzoch and Shabelzoch is everything!
132212.content:
You are drifting through a void. There is no light, no structure, heat, or smells. There is only one sickened young dragon, floating like a leaf on a windless lake. The fires of the clearing are far behind you now- or perhaps in here, they never were. Nothing makes sense for very long as your brain still combats the effects of the poison. You wonder if there is an afterlife for dragons. You had never considered it much before. Surely if this was to be your eternity, the arrow punctures would have been restored prior. Or else some cruel deity saw fit to let souls depart with all of their wounds and ailments. You pondered on that. What happens to a decapitated dragon? What if one starves to death? If an aging dragon passes on, do they continue to age here?

You have some serious grievances with this afterlife. You want another.

Suddenly, the void shudders and ripples as if a current has passed through it. A low rumble permeates the blackness, and like a newborn's wing, it tears apart in a gaping hole. Light blinds you, noises deafen you in their sudden reintroduction. You feel an unbearable squeezing sensation from your tail to your snout and are sucked through the tear, back into reality. The travel leaves your poisoned mind reeling and furious, and out of reflex you lash the surroundings with your tail. You strike a hard, smooth surface with a clink.

As your senses adjust, you see a vast cavern of deep red and black bricks. A barrier has been erected all around you, tapering at the top several tail lengths above your head. The braziers seem to have made their way here as well, although there are only two now, and they have traded their cool black metal for greasy yellow wax. They are accompanied by various other objects: an enormous skull, an obsidian slab, a pool of blood carelessly slopped into an iron tub large enough to bathe in. The smell of angry garlic pervades your new prison, and the cultist's ululations in their demonic tongues assault your ears. You twist about, looking for the nearest human to crush for this outrage. You spy a group of them over a short of expanse of flat cavern floor and across a ridge. There is just one problem...

The cultists are several stories tall.

You reexamine your surroundings and come to a revelation: this is not a barrier, it is a bottle. The braziers are candles, the ridge is the edge of an altar, and the cavern is a filthy, murky room with no windows. The void must have been some rite of the cultists' to spirit you away from the clearing, and now you are no larger than a dwarven tea cup. You strike the glass bottle's edges with your claws and are rewarded only with more paltry clinks. You take a breath, let your chest ignite, and blast the bottle's top with a jet of flame. It produces a feeble yellow flicker that hardly even singes the cork. In a rage, you slam your full weight into the glass on one side and the other, first the bottom, then the top. The bottle only surrenders the tiniest rocking before settling back in place.

Trapped! Well and truly trapped! In over a hundred years, you have never known such a feeling of humiliation. It burns hotter than flame.

In this time, the cultists have taken positions in a circle around the altar. They wear blood red robes over their black armor now, and draw the slender swords at their sides to point in the air over a grand five-sided insignia surrounding the altar. Their chanting rises to a fevered pitch. Even with the poison fading, it gives you a headache. Suddenly, in much the same way that you fell through the tear and into this prison, a rift splits into existence overhead. This one seems to claw at existence, greedily pulling at the air around it, ruffling the cultists' robes and setting the candle flames into a frenetic dance. Vile red light pours from within it, and the garlic stench reaches you even through the cork. You feel an unpleasant sensation- like an invisible leech has latched onto your heart. Odd lights and colors emanate from the other items on the altar. The tub of blood drains before your eyes.

Into the world bursts a demon. Even now that it has stretched to thrice its size, the rift struggles to accommodate its bulk. It is mostly red, as one would expect, though its horns are coated in a thin membrane laced with shriveled black veins. Its limbs are disproportionate, heavily muscled in some spots while sickly and frail in others. Its black claws have grown out of control, twisting and spiraling off of its long feet and hands. A sinewy long tail slashes the air behind it as it climbs through the rift. It ends in bones sharpened and carved to resemble a primitive axe. Yellow pustules checker its body, some oozing green pus. Its face is like the bastard child of a bat and a boar, all flaps, rolls, and stretched pink skin. Long tusks stand out from a mouth overflowing with a wolf's teeth. Its jaws seem to be an ill fit for its mouth, as the gums extend out from its lips like a second creature lives in its cheeks. Its eyes are wide and swiveling, bestial and yet filled with an ancient, intelligent hatred. Wherever its gaze rests, light seems to fade. It hops to the old stone floor with a titanic thud and then hunches over, resting on two legs and a hand like a monkey. It towers over its summoners, silent save for labored, nasally breaths.

The cultists lower their blades and raise their hands. One of them steps forward and lowers his hood, revealing a shriveled face obscured by an unkempt grey mustache. He addresses the demon. "Lord Shabelzoch! We, your faithful servants, welcome you into Grethbean!"

The demon gives him the most hideous smile you have ever seen. You wonder if it already plans to eat them. You certainly would. "My ssservants!" it shrieks, delighted. "You have followed my brilliant instructions perfectly! When first I whispered into your hearts, you numbered only three. But now you are..."

Shabelzoch pauses to survey the room, perhaps counting.

"...Much larger in number! Armed, too! Sssplendid work, that is."

The head cultist bows. "We are but worms under your heel, master. With your guidance, we will fill Grethbean with terror.

"Grethbean is only the beginning, my ssservants," the demon hisses excitedly. "When I have taken my fill of this realm, all shall be made into mire and excreta. Then I will feed on the next, and the next, until Shabelzoch is everywhere and everything is Shabelzoch!"

"We will follow you to the end, master," the cultist nods.

The demon looks puzzled for just a moment. "Yes, and, you shall have your reward! Rewards! You will all be rewarded with your greatest desires. It will be great. All of them, every desire you have." The demon throws back its head and gives a shrill cackle. Your ears and eyes burn. "Trust me!"

"We have prepared a sanctum where you can prepare, master," the cultist says. "This shrine is not secure enough. If the lords find us now, it could be a hindrance."

"My clever, clever minions! While no mortal weapon can harm me, I see the wisdom in this plan! Prepare my vessel and let us be off."

The old man blinks. "Uh, vessel, master?"

The great demon's bulging eyes roll. "Yes, my vessel you cretin! The body that shall carry me under guise of a mortal, as I mentioned in my instructions. Do you expect me to walk there!?"

The cultist's face shows no recognition. The demon coughs.

"Or maybe I forgot. Maybe YOU forgot. Who knows. At any rate, you'll do just fine. Move over, I'm driving!"

Shabelzoch takes one large step towards the old cultist, reaches out and pins him between its massive hands. The cultist raises his hands in alarm.

"W-wait master, I..!"

The demon's enormous bulk is solid one moment, viscous like a slug the next. In another, it is like a jelly, and the next a filthy red juice. It flows into the cultist's face through his mouth, nose, ears and even eyes. The old man screams and contorts as much as he is able. Yet it only takes about 20 seconds for the demon's full mass to enter the man. He first goes rigid as a plank. Then a familiar, hideous grin crosses his face.

"Sssee? Perfect fit!" The man says cheerfully. The expression looks somehow even more unnatural on his shriveled features. If the other cultists are terrified, only the one who fainted shows it. The demon's vessel sizes the other cultists up and picks one at random. "You! Put a helmet on or something. You're the new leader while this one is away. Show me to my new sssanctum!"

The new head cultist bows quickly and leads the group out of a passage at the north end of the room, which is suddenly much lighter and quieter. You are left alone in your glass prison to reflect on the events. What would your clan say of all this?

Your clan. The aching fear returns with a vengeance. The cultists have obviously used you in some way to summon the demon, which means that they entered Nosferu with the intent of capturing a dragon. That meant they knew where it was, which meant it wasn't safe. Which meant your clan wasn't safe either, not now, and not on the night of your capture. The evidence was grim, but you couldn't know for sure.

Time passes. With no sunlight or stars, it's difficult to discern how much. Dragons are slow to hunger, doubly so in extreme situations. you try rocking the bottle a few more times to no avail. You try your fire, you try mimicking the cultists' chants from earlier. You finally just try calling for help both in draconian roars and in mortal tongue.

More time passes. You are utterly alone. You dream of flying over the ridges of Nosferu, and wake up in despair.

Still more time passes. You may well find out what happens to a dragon that starves to death in the afterlife. You are well and truly alone. So it seems that this is a rare moment where a baby dragon could be forgiven for allowing himself to cry. Draconian pride is for fire. Draconian grief is wet.

There are two ways this adventure could unfold. One is an ending, the other a beginning.

13222.content:
You remembered the smell of elves from when you were only 100 years old, you flew out to meet them. As you flew you could feel the eyes of the elves on you almost as soon as you started to descend.

"Hail Elves, I am Kihara protector of the clan Beantiv, what business do you have in these lands?" you asked of the elves
"Hail Kihara, I'm Renald, guide for the elvish clan Thrental, we are looking for the lost home of the elves." said one of the small elves in the traditional greeting between the two races.
Thinking back to what you knew of the elves religion and traditions you decided that it was a reasonable excuse for the elves to be so far from the lands they the humans and dwarfs shared searching for their fabled city of origins. you thought it was pure delusion to try to find a city that was billions of years old when the oldest living dragon was only two million ears old, it was silly no city could survive that long with no one caring for it.
"I'll have to report this to the elders, you're welcome to stay here until I return. Move any further and I cannot guarantee your safety from hunters." you said
"how long will you be gone?" asked one of the elves
"not more than a few hours. I'll be back before nights fall." you said taking off and turning east about 200 miles off from where the clan lodged.

1512.content:
You know very little about your parents...
Did they love you?
Did they even want you?

All you know is that..at the age of 3...your parents were at risk of being discovered.
You father, a human, knew that they couldn't stay together.

Your mother left you with some of her trusted elven friends...and went back to the elven capital.
Your father wished you well...and disappeared.
They both knew that if they were discovered...they'd be killed....
And so would you...

You are now 17...it has been over 12 years since that happened.
You have devoted your life to finding them...and getting some answers.
You know it will be hard...

Being a half-elf in a world where humans hate elves..and visa-versa...
But.......
One day, you know you will receive the answers you seek.
